awd_titl_txt: US-Korea-Taiwan Collaborative International Winter School: Beyond Moore's Law
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed project will provide support for graduate students and postdocs to travel to Korea to attend the International Winter School:  Beyond Moore?s Law.  The project is modeled after the Advanced Study Institutes conducted around the world on various subjects.

Intellectual Merits 
This project will provide an outstanding educational opportunity for graduate students and postdoctoral fellows to examine and overcome the fundamental and technological challenges encountered in the continuing the miniaturization of modern microelectronic devices.  Emphasis will be placed on novel nanoelectronic technologies that depart significant from scaling of conventional field-effect transistors.  The speakers, all leading scholars in their fields, will be recruited from Asia, the US, and Europe.  

Broader Impacts
The organizers will stress interactions between graduate students, postdocs, and international faculty, to ensure that junior scientists have ample opportunity to meet not only current leaders in their fields, but also develop contacts among their international peers for potential future collaborations.

por.por_cntn:
In this project we support for a collaborative effort between three different countries – the US, South Korea, and Taiwan – by supporting the US participants to International Winter School: Beyond Moore's Law (BML), which
was hold in Jeju Island February 1-5, 2010 in South Korea. This Winter School is targeted for junior scientists (graduate students and postdoctoral fellows) from US, Korea and Taiwan in order to seek the new approaches and paradigms for addressing the pending end of the Moore’s law scaling in microelectronics.  The School, which featured 10 lectures by internally
renowned scientists and the poster session by all the participants, created a
new venue in which to explore the frontiers of nanotechnology and developed a vision of research directions for the next generation scientists and engineers. The School provided an important educational opportunity for a select group of approximately 100 attendees from the three countries who wished to pursue careers in the emerging nanoscale science and technology research areas. There were 23 US junior participants we supported fellowship to support their travel expense from this grant. The Winter School offered the participants a unique opportunity and received very positive feedback from the students.

We selected 24 graduate students and postdocs from the leading US Universities to participate in the Winter School. The US junior participants’ expenses including airfare, local transportation to the conference site, and other justifiable local expense were supported from this grant. The Winter School examined several promising new nanoelectronic technologies that hold promise of responding to these needs. The sponsoring agencies from Korea, Taiwan and the US have assembled an international group of distinguished lecturers who provided guidance through formal lectures, as well as via more informal sessions in which the attendees asked a lot of questions and interacted with those same lecturers. The School clearly oriented this selected group of attendees in their career choices in the emerging research areas of nano-electronics and to assist them in becoming leaders in finding new stratagems for continued advances in the field of information technology.

The School also helped in establishing relations between young scientists from different countries, relations that sow the seeds for future international collaboration. These interactions will certainly naturally lead to long-term collaboration and exchange of personnel. The junior participants (U.S. graduate students and postdoctoral associates) enjoyed the benefit not only from lectures by leading experts, but also from interactions with international peers who are likely to emerge as future leaders in science and technology. Finally, the project also helped to highlight the successful achievement of Columbia Nanocenter for its 10th year of anniversary by bring in the former graduate students who worked on nano-electronics and further have developed their carrier afterward in order to share their experience and encourage current graduate students in the center. 

In view of the magnitude of the challenge in replacing the highly developed silicon CMOS platform, an international effort is required.  It will not be easy to
overcome the technological challenges in going beyond the limits of Moore’s
law, and internationally concerted efforts among the leading research countries become essential. The support from this project thus greatly helped to establish relations among young scientists from the different participating countries, which will in turn facilitate future international collaborations.
